Program Description: A two-year diploma program designed to help students strengthen academic skills and refine goals for further post-secondary studies, with articulation agreements enabling pathways to selected degree programs. Includes a wide range of required courses in arts and humanities, social sciences, and science, as well as two liberal studies elective courses. Emphasizes the development of research, writing, oral communications, and critical thinking skills.

Context:
The George Brown College offers a General Arts and Science (R101) diploma program that lasts for two years (four semesters). This program provides excellent preparation for university studies as it emphasizes advanced skills in research, writing, oral communications, and critical thinking. Students can pursue various career options upon graduation or continue their education through university transfer or vocation-specific college studies.

For university studies, students with a program GPA of 3.0 or higher may be eligible for admission to The University of Toronto (U of T) with up to 6.0 transfer credits and the opportunity to enroll in spring/summer courses. Students who meet the grade point average requirements may also be granted exemptions or advanced standing in other college programs.

Students can pursue a degree pathway at U of T through this program, and those who don't plan to continue their education can develop advanced communication and critical thinking skills valued in many workplaces.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/General Arts and Science Program (Diploma) R101 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The General Arts and Science program at the college requires at least one year of university studies for admission, with specific requirements depending on grades and the chosen university and program. Students must adhere to both program-specific and institutional requirements of the universities to which they apply. Graduates may apply for entry into certain programs at the University of Sussex in the UK and George Brown's business, hospitality, and technology degree programs.

Required courses for the first semester include COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts, GSCI 1024: Environmental Science, HUMN 1111: Critical Thinking: A Reasoning Experience, MATH 1034: Mathematics for General Arts & Science, SSCI 1011: Learning and the Brain, and HUMN 1035: Introduction to Media Studies.

For the second semester, students are required to take SSCI 1106: Introduction to Research, HUMN 1114: Reasoning and Rhetoric: Reading Between the Lines, GSSC 1055: Fundamental Themes in Geography, STS 1035: Exploring Career Options, and either MATH 1094: Calculus or a math elective of their choice. They must also take one science elective from options including GSCI 1065: Human Biology, GSCI 1045: Nutrition, or GSCI 1146: Plants and Society.

In the third semester, students are required to take HUMN 1029: Introduction to Philosophy I, HUMN 1032: Foundations of Canadian Culture, HUMN 1034: Introduction to Canadian Literature, SSCI 1012: Introduction to Psychology I, and SSCI 1013: Introduction to Sociology I. They must also take a liberal studies elective.

In the fourth semester, students are required to take HUMN 1030: Introduction to Philosophy II, HUMN 1031: Canadian Studies, HUMN 1033: Critical Approaches to Literature, SSCI 1015: Introduction to Psychology II, and SSCI 101 (information missing for this course).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/General Arts and Science Program (Diploma) R101 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information about various courses offered in the General Arts and Science (R101) two-year diploma program at the college. These courses include "Critical Approaches to Literature" (SSCI 1015), "Introduction to Psychology II" (SSCI 1014), "Introduction to Sociology II", a Liberal Studies Elective, and potentially "COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication)". Students may need to take this communication course before progressing to COMM 2000.

The college has articulation agreements with several universities such as the University of Toronto, University of Waterloo, Bishop's University, Athabasca University, Royal Roads University, Vancouver Island University, Buffalo State University, and University of Sussex Law program. Students can transfer some credits earned in the R101 program to these universities for a university degree.

The graduates from this program are expected to demonstrate abilities like developing insights into self and society, flexibility and clarity of thought and expression, employing critical thinking processes, examining societal aspects, and using basic vocational skills.

Tuition fees for domestic students for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022 is $3,786.00, while international students pay $17,503.00 for the same period. Fees are subject to change for programs starting at later dates.

International students are advised to visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information. The text does not provide any specific financial assistance details.

Context:
The text provides information on various aspects of applying to George Brown College, specifically for the School of Liberal Arts and Sciences. Here's a summary of factual information:

1. International fees and related costs can be found on a separate page.
2. Financial assistance is available for eligible OSAP applicants.
3. Admission requirements include an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), or Mature Student Status with the option to take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade credits.
4. Course exemptions may be granted based on college or university credits.
5. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges and international students through George Brown College Online Application System.
6. Contact information: School of Liberal Arts and Sciences can be reached at 416-415-5000, ext. 2009 or gas@georgebrown.ca; general inquiries can be made by contacting the George Brown College Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or 1-800-265-2002; international students can also contact recruitment representatives through virtual meetings or inquiries.
7. Campus visits: Sign up for an information session or book a campus tour at Casa Loma Campus, located at 160 Kendal Ave., Toronto, Ontario.
